item.description: In Codon: The DNA Game, you are a student scientist competing against other scientists to determine the structure of five proteins involved in five common human diseases: cancer, AIDS, cystic fibrosis, muscular dystrophy, and diabetes. Each scientist player will roll the DNA Dice to identify the amino acids in these five human proteins. The scientist who identifies the most amino acids will earn the most points and win the game.

name.value: On The First Day of Christmas

item.description:
The 80-card deck contains cards ranked from 12 to 1 based on the "Twelve Days of Christmas" Christmas carol, along with two Wild Cards. There are twelve 12s, eleven 11s, and so forth, with a single card ranked 1. The lower the number, the better the rank.

Before starting, each player draws a card to determine their position. Lowest number is the King/Queen, up to the highest number being the Junior Townsperson. The Wild card counts as 13 for this.

The deck is dealt out to all players and the object is to get rid of your cards as fast as possible. The hand begins with one person playing one or more card to the center of the table. The cards played must all be of the same rank (Wild cards may be played with any other cards). Each player in turn must now either play the same number of cards of a better rank, or pass. Play continues around the table until everyone has passed; at that point, the cards are cleared and whoever played the last set of cards leads the next round. After everyone has gone out, the players are ranked. For example, the person who first got rid of all his cards becomes the new King/Queen. At the end of each round, points are tallied based on the new position. King/Queen is 5, Prince/Princess (second) is 3, Duke/Duchess (third) is 2 and all others are Junior Townspeople are 1 point. Players then change seat position to represent the new hierarchy and begin another round. Highest score at the end of 5 rounds wins.

Gameplay is like The Great Dalmuti, except that game has a finite end after 5 rounds, and maximum players are 6 instead of 8.

PiramiKa is a board game based chips in ancient Egyptian gods and culture.

At some point in the history of gaming chips Egyptians took shape and was born chess.

This game is an attempt to return the chips to a board where the chips are the Egyptian gods that depending on the nature of each god endow them with special powers.

The game flows out on a board where players can develop different strategies and should capture the god Ka / Ra to win the game.

But like in ancient Egypt, the Nile River has its importance random events creating different depending on the date provided by the board calendar, which is responsible for registering the course of days and nights of the week is up, which turn up the months of the year according to the ancient Egyptians saw, besides other event has been included as a force that is even above the gods who make up the game, this is Khepri the Egyptian scarab.

As in the game of chess mathematical possibilities are endless, but PiramiKa not a game of chess and each player can plan a strategy to capture the god Ra / Ka of his opponent in many different ways.

Battles are an important part of the game, various meetings with Khepri the beetle will have their importance if exceeded, each god may assert his power, but if he loses the game shall be removed and this battle can not be avoided, as to the battles between gods a balanced strategy can result in losing or winning the game.

On components of the game are easy to manufacture and this PnP version I included only black and white for anyone who wishes to try the game.

The game is complete and tested, with special care the balance between players and relation to the different components, a large development behind this game is based on the understanding the world who had the ancient Egyptians, as well as an equally important support in mathematics they used.

Definitely try to create a balanced game with a strong mathematical basis while the chance may frustrate the most brilliant strategic plans established by the players, so the perfect balance between them will win the player plus a proper strategic approach in as far as possible take into account the possibility that chance might hold both players during the course of the game.


PiramiKa es un juego de tablero que basa sus fichas en antiguos dioses egipcios y su cultura.

En algún momento de la historia las fichas de los juegos egipcios tomaron forma y nació el ajedrez.

Este juego es un intento por devolver las fichas a un tablero donde las fichas son dioses egipcios a los que dependiendo de la naturaleza de cada dios se les doto de poderes especiales.

El juego se trascurre en un tablero donde los jugadores podrán desarrollar diferentes estrategias y deberán capturar al dios Ka/Ra para ganar el juego.

Pero al igual que en el antiguo Egipto, el rió Nilo tendrá su importancia creando diferentes eventos aleatorios dependiendo de la fecha que proporciona el tablero calendario, que es el encargado de registrar el trascurso de días y noches de las que se componen las semanas, que a su vez componen los meses del año según los veían los antiguos egipcios, ademas otro evento ha sido incluido como una fuerza que esta incluso por encima de los dioses que componen el juego, este es Jepri el escarabajo egipcio.

Al igual que en el juego del ajedrez las posibilidades matemáticas son infinitas, pero PiramiKa no es un juego de ajedrez y cada jugador puede planear una estrategia para capturar al dios de Ra/Ka de su oponente de muy diferentes formas.

Las batallas son una parte importante del juego, los diferentes encuentros con Jepri el escarabajo tendrán su importancia si es superada, cada dios podrá hacer valer su poder, pero si pierde deberá ser retirado del juego y esta batalla no podrá ser evitada, en cuanto a la batallas entre dioses una equilibrada estrategia puede dar como resultado el perder o ganar la partida.

Sobre los componentes del juego son de una fácil fabricación y en este PnP solo incluí la versión en blanco y negro para quien lo desee pueda probar el juego.

El juego esta completo y comprobado, cuide especialmente el equilibrio entre jugadores y relación con los diferentes componentes, hay un gran desarrollo detrás de este juego que está basado en la forma de entender el mundo que tenían los antiguos egipcios, así como un no menos importante apoyo en las matemáticas que utilizaron.

En definitiva intente crear un juego equilibrado con una importante base matemática a la vez que el azar puede malograr los más brillantes planes estratégicos establecidos por los jugadores, de esta forma el perfecto equilibrio entre ambos darán la victoria al jugador que además de un planteamiento estratégico correcto, en medida de lo posible tenga en cuenta las posibilidades que el azar pueda deparar a ambos jugadores durante el trascurso de la partida.

Crusader States is a non-collectible card game for 3-5 players. Each player represents one of the major European crusader factions as they attempt to carve out a kingdom during their march to the Holy Land.

Cards represent key nobles, money, cities, soldiers and titles as well as events and battles. By skillfully playing your hand you attempt to form a kingdom that is both powerful in votes and powerful enough to fend off the lurking Saracens as well as your fellow crusaders.

Objective: be the first player to reach the Check Out after collecting one grocery disc for each item on your shopping list
 - moving/acting by turn -
spin & move according to the number along the trail; you may move forward or backwards, but in one direction only;
collect grocery discs, spread on the trail (only those, which are on your list);
meeting another player (ending on the same space) you may pick one disc from him/her;

In the 19th century, shortly after the industrial revolution, railways quickly spread over the world. Japan, importing Western culture and eager to become one of the Grand Nations, saw the birth of many private railway companies and entered the Golden Age of railways. Eventually, as a result of the actions of powerful people and capitalists, many of these smaller companies gradually merged into larger ones.

In Trains, the players are such capitalists, managing private railways companies and striving to become bigger and better than the competition. The game takes place during the 19th and 20th century in the 2012 OKAZU Brand edition, whereas the 2013 AEG/Pegasus edition is set in modern times, with bullet trains, freight trains and more. You will start with a small set of cards, but by building a more effective deck throughout the game, you will be able to place stations and lay rails over the maps of Osaka, Tokyo or other locations. The trick is to purchase the cards you want to use, then use them as effectively as possible. Gain enough points from your railways and you will ultimately manage the most powerful railroads in modern Japan!

Trains is the first title in AEG's Destination Fun series! Continue your travels in the acclaimed Planes and Automobiles board games.

Integrates with Trains: Rising Sun

item.description:
1969 is a push-your-luck style game in which players take the role of the leader of a particular nation's space program attempting the first successful lunar landing mission.

Each turn, players use their income to hire scientists to research technology to improve their chances, hire spies to slow other players down, purchase cards to influence their missions and their competitors, or attempt easier, preparatory missions. Players gain victory points for performing well on prep missions, attracting famous scientists to their cause, and of course, how far they got on the moon landing mission.

The core of the game are the mission tests, which consist of rolling five dice. Dice have success, neutral, and failure results, which add to your success rating, do nothing, or subtract from your success rating respectively. The total of your successes will determine the points earned from the mission and whether you'll get a bonus on the final lunar mission. Die rolls can be affected by technology and your success can be affected by having scientists researching relevant techs and card play (from a player or their opponents).

1969 combines simple dice mechanics with elements of resource management and even some light engine building to make an interesting light weight experience. There are some mechanics of player interference (meaning players can disrupt each other's progress) but these elements may be avoided if desired.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

As owners of a fantastic steam park, you're to build gigantic, coal-powered rides to attract as many visitors as you can – but building attractions won't be enough. You'll also need to manage your employees, invest in advertising in order to attract and please the different kinds of guests visiting your park, and, above all, keep the dirt that your park produces under strict control!

Steam Park is an easy-to-learn game with two difficulty levels: one for the less experienced gamers and a more strategic one for those who want a more exciting challenge. In this management game, you'll have to build your own amusement park and make it the largest and most profitable in the region. By constructing the three-dimensional, wonderful rides designed by Marie Cardouat, you will see your park grow right before your eyes. Choose your strategy! Build Stands to attract more Visitors, or Toilets to keep the Dirt under control. Whatever decision you take, take it quickly: The less time you spend planning, the more time you'll have to maintain your park. Thanks to a clever, original action-choosing mechanism, winning in Steam Park is as much a matter of being the best as of being the fastest!

item.description:
In the modular game Countdown: Special Ops, you are in charge of a special ops team with a special mission! Find hidden bombs and dismantle them, help hostages into safety, or take out terrorist leaders. Due to the high variation in goals, targets, threats and specific circumstances, players need to choose their set-up and strategy each time they start a mission or a campaign. Don't just throw in grenades with your buster at public places such as airports and train stations, or else civilians might get hurt, resulting in negative points on your mission balance. (Plus, you know, injuring civilians is not cool.) Develop your primary skill, but don't neglect your attack power, defense power and other skills if you want to stay alive in this thrilling new game.

Countdown: Special Ops is fully modular, with players being able to create their own game by adjusting four different aspects of play:


 Game situations: With more than 200 playing cards, the challenges and threats are different each time you play.
 Game mode: You can play a single mission, a campaign or a scenario; each game mode has its own level and duration, and you're advised to start with a single mission on the lowest level (green).
 Level up: Did you succeed a few times on level green? If so, you might want to try the next (orange) level or even a scenario, that is, three missions in a row with increasing difficulty!
 Goals: Even players' goals can be altered. Countdown: Special Ops is a co-operative game, but if you'd like to change the rules, you could add one or two traitors to the team and play "Traitor Mode".


Development
You can develop your own Special Op by improving his or her skills. This is done in scenario or campaign play. This brings out interesting aspects of the game in which you have to choose how many risk you want to take to gain extra experience or if you want to move slow and stay alive at all cost...

This variation, combined with the 30-minute time limit per mission, makes the experience of a mission "feel" like an actual PC game in many aspects. Smart development is essential to survive the missions on higher threat levels.

item.description:
City building has never been so easy: Just roll the dice, then build a building. However, each die must be selected carefully to fit the building requirements. Push your luck too far – or select carelessly – and a player may find himself demolishing his city instead of building it up. Choose each die wisely and build efficiently in order to erect magnificent skyscrapers and create the best skyline!

Skyline is a quick push-your-luck dice game involving set collection. Unlike other dice games that provide no relationship from turn to turn and no player interaction, this game allows players to literally build upon their decisions each turn and react to their opponents' actions.

Each turn, players choose to roll dice from either the Construction Yard or the Abandoned District, with the goal of erecting urban buildings. Buildings are made up of three types of dice: Ground Floor dice, Mid-Floor dice and Penthouse dice. Some buildings are safer to build but provide little reward, while other buildings have poor probabilities but can have substantial impact on the success of a player's skyline.

After rolling their selected dice, the player must use at least one of these dice to take one of three possible actions: Abandon, Build, or Cancel Construction. The Build action is the desired outcome, of course, but can be carried out only if the die result matches what they need to build. For instance, all Ground Floor dice can be built without restriction, but a High-Rise Mid-Floor die result can be built only on top of a High-Rise Ground Floor die. Likewise, a Mid-Rise Penthouse die can be built only on a Mid-Rise Mid-Floor die. If the rolled results do not allow them to Build, then the player must Cancel Construction on one of their existing buildings. If a player does not want to Cancel Construction, then they must Abandon by placing that die in the Abandoned District, which gives their opponents the opportunity to capitalize on this failure.

At the end of the game, points are rewarded for completed buildings according to their height. A Level 3 building – that is, a building comprised of three dice – is worth 9 points, while a Level 4 building is worth 16, and so on.

Remember, the dice control the results...but the players control the dice.

name.value: Auf geht's mit der Rheinischen Post

item.description:
A promotional Game by a regional newspaper for cultural attractions in the Rheinland region in the West of Germany.

Players roll a die and move a pawn along a track through the region "discovering it" by drawing and reading cards when they land on certain spaces.

User summary
A fantasy golf themed card game. Players choose different characters and a stage consisting of a series of cards is created. All players start at the first card, and try to pass them in order by playing cards from their hand, by exceeding the stage card level with the card they play. All cards have a specific effect and can be played to hinder other players from advancing.

The player with the most points after 3 stages wins.

Published in Game Market 2004.

The game is composed of 2 rounds.
In the first round, players bids to get his monster, its 4 attacks, its 3 defenses, its 2 special abilities and its 1 weakness. Now, each player has his monster with 4 attacks and 3 defenses and 2 special abilities and 1 weakness.
In the second round, each player attack one of other monster in agility order.
The game ends when only one monster survive the second round.

Ascari is a company-level game based on the stories of loyal solders who fought for Italy in Eritrea, the first Italian colony. The game depicts four battles in which the Italians were the protagonists: the two battles of Agordat against the Dervishes, Amba Alagi, and Coatit against the Ethiopians. A bonus scenario depicting the battle of Metemma between the Dervishes and the Ethiopian Emperor Johannes IV is also included.

Here are the description of the Scenarios:
S1 First Agordat:
A raiding party of Dervishes are caught by the Ascari troops commanded by Captain Gustavo Fara in the plain of Agordat.

S2 Agordat:
2200 native Askari and some Italian national soldiers, led by Lt. Colonel Arimondi, encounters in the plain of Agordat around 12,000 Mahdists, led by the Amir of Ghedaref, attempting to invade the Italian Colony of Eritrea. An astonishing Italian victory and the very first one of the young nation.

S3 Coatit:
The Italian Army in Eritrea, led by General Baratieri, wins its last victory before Adowa, attacking the overhelming Ras Mangasha’s Army at Coatit, fighting two days and performing a perfect redeployment under enemy fire. Tactically a draw, but stra-tegically a victory.

S4 Amba Alagi
The political quarrel between Gen. Arimondi and Eritrea Governor Baratieri led the IV Native Bat-talion to be put in the advanced position of Amba Alagi, just in front of the full Negus Menelik Ethiopian Army. Arimondi wanted to repeat Agordat, when with few troops managed to win the day, and therefore, despite Baratieri’s order to withdraw the Battalion, he didn’t forward it to Lt. Toselli, condemning hime and his men to sure death… it will be the prelude to Adowa!

S5 Metemma
After the sack of the historic capital city of Gondar in 1888, Negus Neghesti Johannes IV gathered an army to repel the Mahdists from the city of Metemma. While on the way to victory, the Ethiopians melt away demoralized by the killing of their Emperor during the final assault.

It is a race to get to the race! Be the first player to complete all four auto maintenance tasks and get to the racetrack finish line to win.

2-4 players move around the outer portion of the game then to the inner track. If a player makes it to the center track without completing all tasks that player must continue to do laps around the inner track until the car mainenance is finished.

The first player to make it to the racetrack finish line and have completed all four maintenance jobs wins the game.

Contents:
1 Game board
4 pawns
1 die
24 game tiles (6 oil change, 6 paint job, 6 new set of tires, 6 tank of gas)

name.value: Caleórn y la Maldición del Lobisome

item.description:
We are in northern Spain in the late ninth century. The mercenary camp led by Basurde has been cursed; his men are butchered by a dreadful beast. Thus, Basurde, his adopted son Gilem, and Sabba a mysterious and strange monster-buster woman decide to investigate these events and put an end to the killing.

They discover a Basurde’s old sorceress enemy behind all this. She’s well protected inside her cave, built with powerful magical defenses which can only be broken by placing three stellar rocks at its entrance.

Each player’s goal is finding a stellar rock and face together the sorceress in her own cave, the Den of Wolves. A series of tests and challenges will be required before the rocks are reachable. Meanwhile, the player who controls the sorceress will also control all the enemies and events happening to the adventurers in the game.

The fairies desperately want to return to their home among the stars. For this they need stardust (the lifeforce of fairies) and what better place to find it than in Starfall Forest?

Every now and then a star will come falling down into the forest where the fairies are hiding and waiting. As soon as a stars lands, the fairies are eager to get to it. Moving from tree to tree, as fairies prefer to stay hidden from sight, they all try to get to the star as quickly as possible. Only when a fairy has collected enough stardust can she make it back home to the stars.

So the race to the stars is on! But beware.. There are venomous snakes about. Try not to get bit as this will cost you the precious stardust you so desperately need to go back home.

All fairies will eventually manage to return home, clever as they are. But who will get there first?

An educational card game published by the Dutch Safe Traffic Agency, meant for teaching and checking knowledge of Dutch traffic rules and regulations.

Game contains a to-be-assembled die, cut-out chits and playing cards.

Per round the top card is drawn and a die roll decides which category question or task must be correctly answered to win that category's chit.
Each card contains three traffic rules questions, a pictionary-like assignment (traffic-related: draw a traffic light) and charade-like task (mime turning right on a bike). Each question or task has its own category. The game should be played by teams of at least two players. The team who first collects all 5 different category chits wins.

Admiral of the Black is set in the Golden Age of Piracy. It is both a board game and a deck building game. Players take the roles of pirate captains and compete against each other by raiding merchant ships for trade goods and treasure that earn them Victory Points. They also must visit friendly ports to trade goods, add new crew members, and purchase arms and equipment. These new crew members, arms, and equipment cards are added to their decks.

The board is a map of the Caribbean with a hexagonal grid. Players move on the edges of the hexes while the merchant ships move from one hex to the next. A player may engage a ship in battle when its ship is on a hex edge adjacent to a merchant ship. Once an enemy ship is defeated in naval combat the player may initiate boarding combat.

Both naval and boarding combat are resolved through the player's Naval Combat and Boarding Combat decks. An additional six-sided die is added to the combat score.

The game ends when the Admiral of the Black (the leader of the pirates) is defeated and a new Admiral of the Black is declared by the player with the most Victory Points.

Game description from the publisher:

It’s the game where the right answer is wrong! Teams start at the finish space and try not to get to start. Read the answer that’s on the card, then read the three questions below it. Try to select one of the two WRONG questions. If you do, you stay where you are on the game board – but if you pick the correct question, you move closer to start.

item.description:
In 1982, Mexico's economy collapsed, and the government's response was to centralize the banks and devalue the peso. (This much, at least, is true...)

In the game world of Banditos, the Mexican people responded poorly to these changes, resulting in a decrease in effective security and an increase in creative accounting at the new Banco de Mexico. Once some of the "alternatively principled" people in the land of opportunity heard about this, they looked south of the border for their ventures.

You will play one of several American characters making runs into Mexico to pull bank heists. You will need to acquire vehicles, weapons, seed money, and maybe even some inside information to make it all happen.

The first player to get his character home with the equivalent of one million US dollars wins.

Players can acquire cards (vehicles etc.) by drawing them each turn, by buying them from other players, or by stealing them from the discard pile.

Doing anything deemed illegal, however, will bring "heat" to your character (if you steal from the discard pile or pull a heist,) or your vehicle (if you steal gas or pull a heist,) or Mexican cities (if you pull a heist.) 
It's up to you as a player to manage your risk and decide how desperate you are to acquire what you need versus how much heat you currently have.

If you have the guts to try a risky heist, it'll either pay off or you'll land in a Mexican jail and have to play catch-up.

link.value: Banditos: Hippies and an Armored Truck

item.description:
Subtitled: Skirmish Rules for the Early Gunpowder Era

Mainly for recreating small conflicts during the settling of America. Also can be used to simulate actions in Europe, pirates and Colonial conflicts.

For skirmish combat between up to 80 figures per side. A figure represents one character. Each player command one or two units of 5-10 characters.

Units are activated randomly using cards, then the unit leader consumes Activation Points to make soldiers act.

A ring-bound booklet of 22 pages with a cardstock cheat sheet.
Eleven sample units and Optional rules are provided as Appendix.

A Rummy-like card game with World Literature as theme. Each card represents a famous book from the World Literature, including a (colored) theme, and a short description with highlighted keywords. Players try and lay combinations of cards based on the colored theme (beginners), the keywords in the description (intermediate), or self-defined connections between the books (advanced).

Designed by Dutch writer and journalist Pieter Steinz.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Discovering the tradition of the 19th-century Mazovia region via a card game? Why not! Ryzykanci: Koleje Fortuny (Daredevils: Wheels of Fortune) presents the time of revolutionary industrial changes, political storms, building fortunes, and the first steps of the capitalistic society in Poland. The rail played an important role at that time; it revolutionized transportation, production and trade. Welcome to Mazovia, the world of industrialists, tycoons, magnates and patrons – in other words, daredevils.

In the game you take a role of a famous Polish industrailist from the 19th century and develop your company. The goal of the game is to achieve the highest number of prestige points. Players may gather prestige points through buying shares, building investments (such as Train Stations, Theaters or Boarding Schools) and collecting cash.

The box contains: 110 cards, 16 wood markers and a rulebook with an educational brochure.

The game was prepared for the Mazovian Center of Culture and Art.

This east German game simulates the cosmonaut's training that supposedly boys were always dreaming about. 
The first half of the game is a snakes and ladders part: Players roll dice and move ahead the strenuous training path. On some fields, they are allowed to move ahead fast because of "excellent performances", other field lets them fall behind for "insufficient performances". When a player reaches the 30th field of the track, his or her plastic cosmonaut is inserted into a plastic rocket and is ready for take-off. After rolling a six, the rocket is moved along a path to a distant planet, and the game turns into a basic roll and move game. After skipping a turn on the planet, players take off again and reach earth again on a different path. The first player to return home safely is the winner.

The game is free of political agitation and focusses on the hardships of the cosmonaut's training. It is remarkable that this ancient game (which has only two pages of rules anyway) contains a rule overview on the back side of the rule booklet.

item.description:
Operation Blast is a game of economic and military strategy, playing with cards. You are president of a small republic at war with its neighbors. Thanks to the financial resources you have, you can afford the services of foreign powers to fight the battle.

Your territory, such as your enemies is divided into 10 provinces, materialized by tokens. In different ways, you can destroy your enemies provinces, they can destroy yours, you can rebuild, and they also. When a player's 10 provinces are destroyed, it is eliminated. The last player to have at least one province has won the war.

Apart from the money, there are four types of cards: the production units, combat units, units of action and events. These units belong to foreign powers grouped into five categories: United States, Europe, Eastern Countries, Asia and Arab countries. Depending on the money you have, you can afford the services of these units.

Combat units, such as production units, are placed on the territory of the player. For that, each time he places a card, he must pay the recruitment fee or purchase price, either by using profits from its production, either with cash it may have on hand.

Each unit can only move once per turn. They can either join a production unit to support his defense, or to regroup them (maximum 3 units can be grouped ) or go to war: for this, the player must pay the travel expenses, and the unit then join the combat zone, a "no man's land" in the center of the table. When your opponent has no more unity in the combat zone or to protect his territory , each time you attack him, your attack will destroy a province...

The box says "An Exciting 3 Dimensional Game." Aimed at children under eight years old.

It is a race to see who can get through their 'cheese tunnel' first. Luck and colour recognition are all part of the race.

The tiles are placed face down. Players draw a tile - If it matches their colour they can move their mouse along the tunnel. If it is not their colour, return it to the pack. There are penalties for drawing a cat card.

The first player to get their mouse to the end of the cheese tunnel, wins.

Contents
4 - 3D Cheese Tunnels
4 Mice Holes
4 Mice
24 Mice and Cat Tiles.
1 Cat Backcloth.
1 Set of Rules.

item.description: Party game. Each guest receives a question card. The game takes the form of a quiz where all the answers relate in some way to something used to maka a salad. The guest who gets most right, wins.

Each player deploys his ships secretly on a square grid. Then each player shoots at the other's grid by calling a location. The defender responds by "Hit!" or "Miss!". You try to deduce where the enemy ships are and sink them. First to do so wins. It is extremely similar to the popular game Battleship, the difference being this version uses a pen and paper grid instead of the peg-board found in that game.

Shooting target game not without some humour.

Players take turns shooting at an array of three targets; a pheasant in flight, a duck wading and a gamekeeper reloading his gun. If you hit the pheasant you score 15 points; if you hit the duck you get 10 points, but if you hit the gamekeeper (oops!), you lose 5 points.

First to score a pre-set total of points, wins.

A shooting target game featuring famous images associated with the Outlaw of Sherwood Forest.

The target has four characters. Two mounted Normans and two unmounted knights. I think the mounted character in plain clothes so-to-speak is probably the dastardley Sheriff of Nottingham.

Each player takes turns and the one who has the most successes after a pre-agreed number of rounds, wins.

Traditional quiz game where a player must answer a question by placing the wired connector to the slot of his chosen answer and, if correct, the bulb attached to that answer will light up. Subjects provided are:
Who was, Where is, Translate, History, General Knowledge and one which asked you to write your own questions and answers.
Most correct answers, wins.

Instructions from the rules:
Connect the two wires to a battery - one player should place one of the perforated sheets so that the holes in it fit exactly over the little knobs. Players in turn take the left wander-plug and with it touch any one of the knobs on the question side (the left), then try to find the right answer on the right hand side. If the player thinks he has found the correct reply, the right hand plug should be placed in contact with the knob in the square which he thinks contains the correct answer. When the correct answer is found, the lamp light up.

name.value: The New Game of Aerial Puff Ball

item.description:
A twist on the mechanics used in Blow Football games but this time a lot more abstract and aimed at adults (judging by the image on the box).

This is probably an original Edwardian Parlour Game. The box is placed in the middle of the table with the cup fixed upon the post in the centre. Each player takes a blower (8 included), and placing the coloured balls one by one in the end of it, endeavours to blow them into the box. Each player in turn puffs all the balls, and scores the numbers of the divisions into which they fall. A ball resting in the Cup counts as 25.

The game is won by the player who first scores 50 or 100, as may be agreed when starting.

A tiddlywink variant that requires a lot of tiddle on your wink.

Between the player and the scoring board is a three-dimensional clown illustration. The clown is holding up a hoop. To score anything the player must launch a counter tiddlywink fashion, up through the hoop and then onto the board. I suggest this was quite difficult to accomplish first time.

At the back of the board there is a score board where you can record your successes. First to the end of the scoreboard track, wins

A simple game linked to all things Swiss.

Each player is given 12 counters, 2 of which are put into a pool. The throw of a die determines how far you move. When landing on a numbered square, the player refers to the list of places corresponding with the number and pays to or receives from the pool, the numbers of counters stated.
When landing on a mountain pass - You must pay 1 counter to all other players. Customs squares will cost you 3 Counters!

The player who first reaches or passes No. 132 Basle and takes the pool, and the winner is the one with most counters.

Contents
1 Playing Board.
4 Playing Pieces.
Large Amount of Counters.
1 Die.
1 Set of Rules.

The goal of the game is to find a gem from Finnish province called Ostrobothnia.

Players roll a die and move their button forward trying to find a gem called Star of Ostrobothnia. During the trip players flip tokens and cannot know what they will find. Players can crash to the knife, which is humorically a some kind of symbol of Ostrobothnia, and have to answer a question which asks knowledge of Southern Ostrobothnia. Players can open a token with a gallant hat and it amuses with aphorisms and grumbles. Players can also drift to a prison with Isoontalon Antti and Rannanjärvi, which are famous characters of Ostrobothnia.

In the game players move their buttons in earth, sea and air.

Pirate Hunter is a push-your-luck dice and card game with opportunities for player interaction. Players compete to capture pirates by rolling dice against a challenge number shown on each pirate card. 
Players must manage their dice pool carefully while taking just enough risk to stay ahead of the others.

The more pirates a player captures, the more risk their dice will be lost to Davy Jones along with the plunder accumulated that round.

Some rolls give dice, some rolls send dice to Davy Jones! In a pinch, players may call for the aid of another player and then negotiate a settlement for the assistance. But be careful, those lending aid are also putting their dice at risk.

Will you keep your plunder in your hold and risk the roll with fewer dice or use it to buy back dice and risk not having enough plunder to win in the end?

Box slogan "Exciting Game For All the Family,With All the Thrills of the Track."

The object of the game is to get your greyhound first over the finish line.

Choose your trap number, choose your stake and on which dog you wish to bet on. Fany bets such as Forecasts or Combinations are allowed (although heaven knows what a 7 year old would make of that).

When you land on the special spaces, most tell you to draw a card and follow the instructions. There are good and bad cards draw. Some cards relate to bonuses, reserve dogs, competitive greyhounds, and sprint racing are all part of the game.

The Game of WordHound is played by two to four players. The Object of the game is to make an answer belonging to the category in play from the letters on your letter rack.

During your turn you draw letters from the letter bag, one at a time, until you draw a letter you want to keep. When you keep a letter, your turn is over and you pass the bag to the player on your left. Letters you don't want are placed face up on the letter board where they may be taken by other players. Letters you keep are placed on your letter rack.

The first player to make an answer using all the letters on his or her rack wins the round. The winner scores two points for each letter in his or her answer, plus a bonus equal to the number of the round being played. Other players score one point for each letter in their partial answer if every letter on their rack is used in the partial answer. Players score zero points if there are any unused letters on their rack when the round ends.

An answer may consist of one or more words and may be singular or plural. Blank tiles may be used as any letter and are scored as a letter. Spaces between words and other punctuation are assumed and do not affect scoring.

The player with the highest score after six rounds of play wins the game.

Promotional game published by J S Fry & Sons, a leading manufacturer of chocolate at this time (most famous for the TV adverts for "Fry's Turkish Delight).

A basic roll and move game. The board track covers 'Setting Sail' and ends on the desert island and safety. Obey instructions if you land on special squares. First to arrive at the end of the track, wins.

The game was despatched as a flat-pack, so you had to provide your own playing pieces and dice.

Promotional game published by J S Fry & Sons, a leading manufacturer of chocolate at this time (most famous for the TV adverts for "Fry's Turkish Delight).

A basic roll and move game, taking ideas from Ludo in some places. Each player has four men and their designated start point. The board track covers various encounters with fairground attractions. When you land on one, you must follow the instructions. If you land on another player's piece, that piece is sent back to the start.

First to get all four pices home, wins.

The game was despatched as a flat-pack, so you had to provide your own playing pieces and dice.

Promotional game published by J S Fry & Sons, a leading manufacturer of chocolate at this time (most famous for the TV adverts for "Fry's Turkish Delight).

A basic roll and move game. The board track covers the Expedition Start and ends at the expedition end, where a boat awaits your arrival. Obey instructions if you land on special squares. First to arrive at the end of the track, wins.

The game was despatched as a flat-pack, so you had to provide your own playing pieces and dice.

Game for children to play on long car journeys. The board is magnetic, especially important because the game is intended to be played in a moving car.

Cards provide the things to spot and you can score from 1 to 6 points depending on the rarity of the thing to spot. As you score points, you move your player marker along the track. The one who is furthest up the track, wins.

"A Game for Everyone".

The board has a number of holes in it, of varying sizes. In a turn, the player sets off his spinning top in the start area, with the intention of sending it forward towards the scoring holes. If it falls into a hole, points are scored. It follows that the bigger the hole, the less points are gained.

First to reach a pre-agreed total of points, wins.

One Night Only is a game for 3 to 5 players who each take the role of a Band in their humble beginnings and guide them to the heights of Fame. Players choose actions to increase of Band's confidence so they will be able to play larger and larger gigs - thus gathering more and more Fame (and Money). Next they will bid Cash to hire a Bookie who will use his prestige to get the Bands gigs. Players can even play gigs together as Headliner and Opener. At the end of the game, whoever has the highest Fame, is the Winner!

Patriotic card game, made when Britain actually had an Empire but one that was fading fast.

The objective is to gain certain cards to complete sets. The different feature as that the sets have a differing number of cards within them. For example, to collect Ireland cards, you will need 4 cards to complete the set. But to collect England & Wales cards, you would need 6 cards to complete the set.

When all the possible sets have been collected, the one with the most sets wins.

Very strange game and nothing to do with the more famous Boggle game.

Place the heads on a smooth surface and put an eye-ball in each socket, making sure that the pupils do not show. All players then place a fly disc on their cards in an agreed position, say, at the top of the head. Players then proceed to align the eyes on the fly by moving the card about In any direction or by rotating It. The first to achieve the alignment then decides where all players shall next place the fly. The eyes remain in the position achieved at the end of the first round. The player who is first 3 times is the winner.

Tin-plate game. It consists of a spinner with eight unequal areas. Each area is assigned to a horse and the bigger the are allocated, the shorter the odds for that horse.

Players just place their bets and spin the spinner. After the result, pay the winners and take in the losing bets.

I suspect that it was assumed that you would use counters as the 'money' and the one with the most counters after an agreed number of races, wins.

I can see no reason why adults might play this by using real money instead of counters.

Action game. Each player has three balls that must be loaded into a spring-like device, one at a time. If you press down on the device and then let go, the ball will fly out, hopefully towards the board. On the board are 9 squares, each square having a point value. Furthermore, each square has a fixed ring and the ball must stay within a ring to score. The scores range from 5 to 30 points.

First to reach a pre-agreed total score, wins.

Players build up a wall with many blocks in it. On their turn, they must knock out one block from the wall with the glove end of their bodger. The spinner determines the colour to go but the player chooses which particular block of that colour they want to try to remove.

The first player to dislodge any of their yellow blocks, loses the game.

Rare word game from around the turn of the 20th century. Devised at a "Famous London Literary Club", it was probably a new idea over 100 years ago.

52 cards all feature letters, each with a value that relates to the rarity of the letter in the English language (For example, an E would be 4, a Q would be 1, and so on). This value is important because if a player goes out whilst you still hold cards, then you give him the score of you unused cards - i.e. you are not penalised much for holding 'difficult' letters but you are if you hold common letters.

The game mechanic is simple. In a turn a player may lay as many cards as he wants but he must always have in mind a genuine word that could be spelt out eventually. For example, you might lay an L. The next player lays a T after the L (he is thinking of SALT). The next player might lay an I and an M after the T (he is thinking of ULTIMATE) and so on, until a player is challenged that there can be no such word with that array of letters (By the way, the letters must stay in the order they are laid, there is no rearranging letters). If challenged, a player must prove that he was thinking of a word, and if proven true, he receives payment (counters) from the others. If he was bluffing, he pays out counters to the persoin who challenged him.

When the game time is finished, the one with the most counters, wins.

By the way, in 1900 or so, they must have been aware of Analysis Paralysis because there is a fixed rule 'If you take longer than 30 seconds to play or pass, you forfeit your turn and must draw an extra card into your hand'.
And another oddity, how often are you told to enjoy your game - in Latin? The phrase Experientia Docet!, is used at the end of the rules

In Shadow Agent, inspired by video games like Splinter Cell and Metal Gear Solid, the players take on the role of shadow agents from a non-specified secret agency, with the goal of infiltrating an enemy location (base or mansion) to accomplish a certain mission. The agents must not be seen or heard by the numerous guards walking around the location, so they must hide among the shadows, hide behind walls and furniture, and hit the enemies from behind, being silent the whole time.

At the start of the game, each player chooses up to five items to help with the current mission. Each turn, the active player rolls the action dice and performs two of the rolled actions, which can be Move, Shoot, Melee Attack and Heal. In addition, one die can be replaced by a free action, which range from using an enemy as a meatshield, to interacting with locations, to hiding the corpse of a dead guard.

After a player performs his two actions, the guards – which come in three types: green, yellow and red – are activated. For each type of guard, one player rolls a die twice, with all the guards of this type then performing the rolled actions in order. Actions range from moving 1-4 areas, to shooting, to calling for help (which will spawn other guards). In more detail:


 Green guards move, shoot, and spawn other guards at an average rate.
 Yellow guards shoot and spawn other guards a lot.
 Red guards shoot a lot and move very quickly.


As soon as an alarm sounds due to a guard spotting a dead guard's corpse, all guards are activated with the red die, so things become much tougher for the player agents.

item.description:
A mini game for 2 players by David Smith

Published in Plato magazine

Before You Start


 Draw a large circle and place 9 circular spaces at equal intervals around the circle.
 One player uses 4 small silver coins as pieces.
 The other player uses 4 small bronze coins. 


The Play


 Each player in turn places one of their pieces on the playing board until all but one of the nine spaces is occupied.
 Then each player at each turn must either
 move an own piece into an adjacent space in either direction or
 single jump one own piece over one adjacent enemy piece into an empty space immediately beyond the enemy piece (As in Chinese Checkers) or
 double jump one own piece over two enemy pieces one space apart with vacant spaces between and immediately beyond the two pieces jumper over. (Like a double jump in Chinese Checkers).
 
 Pieces jumped over are captured and removed from the board.
 Last player with a piece or pieces still in play wins the game.


Copyright 2007 David L. Smith, NZ

What turns a young man into a world-saving Hero?

A sacred spear, discovered at just the right moment, might give him the edge he needs to best the evil Fiend. But now the spear is locked in a treasure chest! Better make sure he finds the moon key, which can open any lock. And that mountain pass is home to a red wyrm; he'll probably need some winged boots to make it through in one piece. Perhaps you should place a healing spring on the far side so he can tend his wounds?

Destined Hero is a 2 player strategy game in which you play the forces of destiny trying to raise up a Hero or bring him to ruin. You must have the vision to see what the Hero will need to surmount the tasks that await him, and plant the seeds in prehistory that will bear fruit in the moment of fate. Distribute treasures and allies to aid the Hero, or monsters and obstacles to hinder him, and choose the abilities to bestow upon each. The world you create can make or break the journey as the Hero attempts to make his way to war against the Fiend.

The final battle approaches – but the outcome is surely no mystery to one who sees the threads of fate. After all, it's not really about the Hero... It's about the destiny that awaits him.

Game Data:

Complexity: 2.5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 2 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each unit represents either the Hero or the Fiend in an epic battle to decide the fate of the world.

Game Components:

• One 4-page full color Instructions sheet
• One 4-page full color Player Aid sheet
• One 11” x 17” map
• 45 double-sided 1/2" round markers
• 40 cards
• Includes Designer's Notes and Optional Rules

As with traditional bingo, the goal is to be first to fill in the game card so as to reproduce the pattern selected at the beginning of the game.

Game Cards have boxes to fill in. Though they are all different, the game cards present all of the same combinations. On a total of 25 boxes, you will find 9 différent combinations.

Progress of the game; To get the desired combined value, all players have the right to roll the dice up to 3 times each turn. All six dice must be used for the first roll, but for the 2nd and 3rd rolls, the player has the choice of the number of dice to be rolled.

item.description: Each game of Knock Down Barns begins with two players designing and building their own structure out of small rectangular blocks of reclaimed barn wood. Building is done in secret behind a barn wood divider that crosses the center of the barn wood (or bamboo) playing board. Many strategies are used in building a solid structure as to withstand attack from your opponent. Once both players finish building a structure that is taller than the center divider, the divider is removed before the battle begins. Cylindrical foam weapons are fired by flicking them at each others' structure. Alternate shots and the first player to completely clear the blocks off of their opponent's side of the board wins. It is customary to shake hands with your opponent after every game of #KdB. Remember, You can always build again!©

item.description:
Jesus Christ has promised us that he will be returning, and as a follower of Christ we know that this is true. But what about the people that don't know? Jesus gave us our great commission to go into all the corners of the world and share the gospel, and that is exactly what we will do. 

Your character cards will be your friends, your family and your fellow church members, each with their own set of unique skills and encouragements. When a coal is separate from the fire, it grows cold. Keep great people around you and your faith will grow.

You will also have support, in the form of churches, bible studies, small groups and even education. These support cards will stay in play and give you greater opportunities to travel and spread out across the world. But the mission field starts right at home, will you witness to your neighbor or to a total stranger?

You may travel across the entire globe on mission trips. Some may be only for a single turn (think of it as a youth group trip to the Ukraine or Mexico) and some may take over the rest of the game (such as settling a family in another country, or becoming a pastor for a military branch overseas). Wherever you go, you will always have people to witness to.

The win condition. Sharing Christ's love is not a race, and cannot be kept track of via face down prizes or a life total. So we create a new card type, the Mission card. Therefore go into all of the world, and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them and and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. Each player will have at least one Mission card within their deck, and when you have met your requirements listed on the mission card, you can reveal it to your opponent. The first player to finish their mission does not automatically win however, as the game is not a race. Instead, each Mission has an assigned point value based on its difficulty, and when one player runs out of cards in their deck, whoever has more Mission points wins that game.

Don't think for a moment that lower point values are easy and high point values are hard, remember the woman who gave two coins? Her gifts to the Father were greater than those of the rich men.

Zombie Fried is a card game where you are a survivor of the Zombie apocalypse. My fellow Zombies and I now rule the world, and for some reason you humans are trying to prove to each other that you’re the best Zombie killer. You use the few resources that are at your disposal in an attempt to dispose of me and my kin, or to sabotage the other survivors’ attempts to take out the biggest and best of our kind.

The object of Zombie Fried is to collect the most points in your Brain Pan, because obviously you can’t win without the brains. You do this by (unfairly to me and my friends) bagging Zombies. For those of you who are not strong enough (or too lazy) to bag Zombies on your own, you can hire a Big Damn Hero, or BDH, to bag Zombies for you. You and your BDH use whimsical Zombie killing weapons crafted from the meager resources left after the apocalypse, often modifying them with unusual items to make them inflict more damage on us (innocent) Zombies.

As if weapons weren’t enough, you use Action Plans to help you achieve your goal, often using those same Action Plans to place traps on us poor, unsuspecting Zombies. I can’t be too upset, however, if you’re trapping us to prevent other survivors from killing us. I also fully support your use of Reality Checks to mess with the other pesky survivors’ plans.

So if you dare to challenge me, Lord Dead ‘N Buried, go ahead and try. Foil your fellow survivors’ plans with traps and Reality Checks, equip and enhance your weapons, hire a BDH, and try not to get eaten. If you’re really lucky you might just make it to the Zombie Fried Halls of Honor and Fame.

How many cards are there in the core deck?
There are currently 105 Cards in the core game of Zombie Fried. The game breaks into 2 separate decks that come with the core. Zombies and Resources.

What types of cards are in the core deck?

 ZOMBIE DECK - Zombies are a unique set of Unique Zombies that are rated from "easy to stomp" all the way up to "I think i just wet myself". The Zombie cards are what populate your Killing Field.
 RESOURCE DECK - The Resources Deck comes with several different types of cards that a player may run across.
 Action Plans - These little honey of a cards are cards that a player can either play during thier turn in order to help them defeat the zombie. or they can place it face down under a zombie in the Killing Field as a trap or potential trap to steal. You never know which is a trap and which is a good thing to steal from your opponents when going for a trapped zombie. 
 Reality Checks - are fun. they are card you can play against your opponent to make it more difficult for them to defeat their zombie or there are some Reality Checks that stop of auto-fail the combat of your opponent.
 
 WEAPONS & MODIFICATIONS (MODS) - There are a crazy amount of unique weapons to use. each weapon can be modified with a MOD card that will improve the cards attack power. and some other cards allow you to place more than one mod on a weapon.
 BIG DAMN HEROES (BDH) - These are the last of the warrior breed. you can hire them to do your zombie dirty work for you and equip them with all the crazy weapons you have.

item.description:
A bingo style game with two variants. In the first ruleset, the caller calls out an amount, and the players check their cards which show pictures of coins for a match. A row of four across, three down, four corners or entire card wins (winning pattern announced at the start of the game.

In the second ruleset, the game is the same but the cards and calling are different. Players have a card with coin amounts instead of pictures of coins. The caller calls out a description of a set of coins (i.e. "two dimes and one nickel").

name.value: Special Delivery: A Baby Shower Game

item.description:
Special Delivery is a new and unique baby shower and family board game for the purpose of entertaining baby shower guests and to play at home to reinforce to young children that a new baby is coming into the family. After the game is played with the kids, the months of the trimesters can be crossed off the board as the months pass so that children will get an idea of when the baby will arrive!

This project is a fast moving, hilarious and exciting game for baby showers and couples and family game nights. The game takes an unlimited amount of baby shower guests through delightful scenes of the 3 trimesters of pregnancy as players move their cute minature pink and blue milk bottle tokens up the game board -- from the 1st trimester when the father starts sweating and yanking his collar loose when the doctor tells him he's going to be a daddy, to the 2nd trimester where the now obviously pregnant wife is instructing the bewildered husband to repaint the nursery, and to the 3rd trimester where the anxious mom on a gurney nearly chokes the daddy as she clutches his tie on the way to the delivery room -- while teams take turns trying to draw baby-related words and phrases from the cards in the card box on pink and blue scratchpads. As their teammates successfully guess the word or phrase being drawn, they advance their milk bottle tokens up the gameboard to the Special Deivery space to "deliver their baby." Hilarious sketches and guesses encite non-stop laughter.

Lexicons of Dueling is fast to learn, fast to play, and has hundreds of possible variations to the outcome of a battle! The cards are very easy to understand. The tactics are not just in the cards, it involves you learning your opponent’s style, the way they are thinking, and trying to figure out their next move! While they do the same to you! Each card has defense/attack/body positioning and weapon flow represented in such a way that you could even imagine the actions you are performing as you play.

Game Features:

 NOT a collectible card game. There are no perfect combos other than the ones your opponent didn't block. There are no super rare cards that will imbalance the game to those who can afford them. Every player has an equal chance to win, if they keep their wits about them, or get the opponent to lose theirs.
 Status cards that can increase your chance of victory, but not to the degree that a peasant cannot still best a king, if he plays his cards right. Anybody can win against anybody.
 Simple! Addition and subtraction rules; no tokens, no paper, no life counter, no phases, no arguing rules. The deck is all you need to play..... and an opponent. That will help a lot. You can practice with a single deck random solitaire if you want, but it is much more challenging with a thinking opponent.
 Tournament Play. They all have them, but not all of them will have the flavor of ours. You fight to gain status, from peasant, squire to knight, and so on. As you win you can fight well in higher status tournaments, and one day, maybe fight for the title of King! There are several characters that you can collect during the tournaments, and each of them can become royalty if you succeed!




As a fighter learns he gets better, as they win they gain status in the society they live in. Each status upgrade gives the player an extra skill to survive battles at higher ranks. They can always fight higher ranks than they are, but they can expect to have more of a challenge. They can fight lesser ranks, but they will receive a lesser reward for fighting below their station. The skills fit the rank: a Squire learns to move quickly so gains a dodge. A Knight learns the use of armor for a time, etc. Status cards represent goals and bragging rights you can prove you earned, and skills learned from battle.

This game includes the following expansions; 
- French Rapier
- Two handed Scottish Claymore
- (Introducing) Japanese Katana

item.description:
Astromino -- Dominoes of the Universe

This is a new twist on the age old theme of Domino games from times past. Astromino uses the universe, space travel as an overall game theme. The tiles have the form of the Kite and the Dart, original shapes developed by Sir Roger Penrose as a part of his tiling research projects in the 1970‘s. When “Dominized” these unique shapes open a new set of possibilities for Domino game design and play. Astromino Basic, Full and Advanced Sets are recommended for ages 8 through 101 years. We have play tested Astromino and to date it has done well with all age groups. This Kickstarter Project will be a mega play testing opportunity. The tiles can also be used as blocks or a puzzle just to form shapes and make patterns, it is one way of playing solitaire Astromino.

Astromino Game Sets

 The Basic Astromino Game includes 60 tiles (30 Kites and 30 Darts) with sharp gray scale graphics. Basic game instructions are included.
 The Full Astromino Game includes 100 tiles (50 Kites and 50 Darts) with four color graphics. Full game instructions are included with this set of tiles. Two playing surfaces for the more complex games, approximately 22” x 34” with game instructions make the Full set into an Advanced Game of Astromino.




Astromino Game Play Basics

 To start the game “Big Bang” the tiles, i.e. shuffle or mix them face down on a large table top to form the “Galaxy”. Now choose a tile to determine who starts the game. The player with the highest double tile will be the starter. Once the starter is determined the other players return the tile to the Galaxy as the starter places his double to start the game.
 Now each player will choose their own hand from the Galaxy, 5 Kites and 5 Darts. Each contestant plays one tile per turn from their hand of ten tiles, matching like numbers on the tiles, long edges to long edges and short to short. The basic game continues as a string of connected shapes the Moon and the Star take shape. These shapes Moon and Star must be formed using 5 Kites or 5 Darts, respectively. The shapes are assembled and connected, one to another as the game proceeds. The string of shapes undulates and forms the line of play, always a unique field of play. Like Domino games a typical hand in an Astromino game will last between 15 and 25 minutes.
 Tiles may fit here or there and need to be turned and matched in your head as you choose your next move. Careful don’t make an “Anti-matter” move or if caught you will lose your turn! Strategy comes into play as you make plans for your next move to defeat your favorite opponent(s). Hide your tiles using the Player Tray.
 If you are lucky maybe you can “Shoot the Moon”, it is a play where you complete any shape and clear your hand by playing two (2) or more tiles all at once. Astromino rules include many options so you can choose from them and play the game as you like it.




Game Options

 There are six diferent games each one can incorporate these options to some degree. Play options include Rule of Seven, Blank is a wild to play, Add a Shape, Shoot the Moon, and scoring sevens or just scoring tile values with extra points for completing a shape.




Winning the Game

 Although optional scoring rules are included, the main goal of the game is to use all the Astromino tiles in your hand. When you are down to your last Astromino tile yell “ASTEROID!” Fair warning to the opponents you are about to defeat. You win the hand when all your tiles are played. You win the game when you win two hands. Maybe you will be lucky enough to “Shoot the Moon” for the win.




Six Unique Games in one!

 Basic Line of Play Game
 Moons and Stars Game
 Sun, Earth and Moon Game
 Sumerian Sevens and Twelves Game
 Freeform Penrose Tiling Game
 Four-Stage-Star Game

Pitch It! - Who's Got the Million Dollar Idea? is a dynamic and social game requiring blissfully creative nonsense, but also a keen eye and sharp ear for what’s marketable. It is both fun and challenging! You are charged with the task of selling conventional products to unconventional clientele.

HOW TO PLAY
A combination of ‘What?’ card (product) and ‘Who?’ card (target audience) is picked. The goal for you (or your team) is to sell the ‘what’ to the ‘who’. For example, ‘potting soil’ needs to be sold to ‘police officers’, or ‘bath toys’ to ‘bankers’, or ‘sunscreen lotion’ to ‘NASCAR fans’…you get the idea. Summon your creative mojo to come up with a catchy idea for product title, slogan, and logo. Then pitch your best ideas to your friends. After that, sit back and listen to what others have done. Vote for the best idea presented – it may be yours, but nobody can vote for themselves. The winner of the most votes gets the $1 Million prize for that round. Play more rounds until someone reaches the ultimate goal of $5 Million.

name.value: Live It Up: A Game About Drugs and Consequences

item.description:
Live It Up: A Game About Drugs and Consequences is a fun family game which educates about the serious consequences of drug use while reinforcing the positive aspects of a drug-free life. The primary purpose of Live It Up is to be used as an educational tool, but it is an enjoyable game that can be played casually by adults and young people as well.

Live It Up is a useful visual, audio, and kinetic learning tool. Parents and Educators can play Live It Up with their preteens and teens, while Therapists also will find Live It Up useful for rehab patients.

Live It Up is played with five kinds of cards: Live, Activity, Arrest, Overdose, and Sober cards. The cards are laid out face down on the table. Each player chooses cards and stacks them until they receive a Live card, in which case their turn is up. If a player pulls an Arrest card, their stack of cards go into Jail, only to be redeemed by a player who pulls a Sober card. If a player pulls an Overdose, all their cards go to The Grave, never to be played again. Players can choose to redeem their Sober cards whenever on their turn they wish, but the longer they wait, the more they risk having their own cards sent to Jail or the Grave. The object of the game is to build the most fulfilling life, and the player with the greatest stack of Live, Activity, and/or Sober cards wins.

The object of this game is to move your pawn along "love tracks" and reach the finish square. Rolling a die determines how far along the "love track" you may move on your turn. In so doing, you win time to kiss the person of the opposite sex closest to your pawn. When you land on a square with a heart sign, cupid sign, male sign, or female sign, you draw a card with the matching sign and follow the instructions. The first person to complete all of their card-driven tasks and reach their finish square first, wins the game.

From the game box: "Seven Minutes in Heaven is an entertaining game that will liven any party. The object is to strategically race along love tracks and reach the finish squares. You will find the journey sensuously exciting, intellectually stimulating, and emotionally thrilling. This game is a unique "ice breaker", because the fun experienced along the love track makes everyone a winner."

In an alternate history on the brink of global war, the rare telonite ore has been identified as the key to the revolutionary superweapon that could end hostilities before they begin. Unfortunately this ore only exists in meaningful quantities in a small, blighted archipelago in a remote area. Your superiors cannot spare many men or resources - it would be strategic suicide to move important units from their existing positions - but you've been given the vital task of securing enough telonite to ensure the victory of your nation. Unfortunately, the other world superpowers have sent task forces of their own...

Conquest of the Skies is a light 4X in which 2-3 players compete to gather sufficient quantities of ore before anyone else. Players will explore the abandoned archipelago, research and develop new technologies, manoeuvre airships and giant warships into combat, harvest the meagre supplies of food to keep their people alive and try to be the first to obtain enough telonite ore, by fair means or foul.

Play proceeds via an action point allowance, with each of a player's settlements granting a number of action points which can be used for harvesting resources, researching technologies and acting with units; however, food is almost as scarce as ore, and players must be sure to harvest enough to feed each settlement every turn.

item.description:
Promotional game made by Waddingtons for Blue Label Fyffes Brand of bananas. Fyffes were the most famous supplier of bananas in Britain, mainly thanks to a catchy TV advert featuring the slogan "Unzip a Banana".

Top Banana is based on the Banana Industry, its pitfally and its successes. You travel around the banana-shaped board, buying plantations and then shipping your produce to the marketplace in Britain.

Although it is a familiar type of game, suggested by Monopoly, income is dependent on that which you can raise by making and selling (there is no "Collect 200 when you pass go").

The richest player wins if 'time' is called or if that player is the only one still in business.

The King is dead! Cardis has fallen...

After a long siege, the empire of Asmidan has conquered Cardis and the Conclave of Law has been sent by the Emperor to establish the new rule. The city is in disarray and several factions struggle for power behind the scenes. The former Queen is using her influence to gather allies in an effort to help her son claim the throne. The Order of the Coin — a group of wealthy individuals — wants to rise to power ensuring the gold keeps flowing. The Asmidan's Church desires to seize control of the newly conquered city by using the feared Inquisition to sway whoever opposes it.

In Shadows over the Empire, players take the role of leaders of four factions in a struggle for control of Cardis. They must influence various personalities and have them do their bidding. Loyalties are constantly changing and great allies become mortal enemies in a city filled with desire for dominion. Who will prevail?
